statement.text: The saphenofemoral junction (SFJ) is the anatomic confluence where the great saphenous vein terminates in the common femoral vein, characterized by the terminal valve, multiple named tributaries ('crosse'), and consistent relationships to the femoral artery and inguinal ligament essential for surgical and endovenous procedures.
statement.formal: SFJ_Location: 2-4cm inferior to inguinal ligament, 3-4cm inferolateral to pubic tubercle, medial to femoral artery

explanation.intuition: The SFJ is like a major highway interchange where the main surface road (GSV) joins the deep underground highway (CFV). At this junction, there's a critical one-way gate (terminal valve) and several smaller roads (tributaries) that all converge, making it a complex surgical landmark.
explanation.key_insight: The terminal valve at the SFJ is the 'first line of defense' against reflux. When it fails, blood regurgitates into the GSV with each heartbeat, driving the development of varicose veins. Understanding SFJ anatomy is essential because inadequate surgical treatment of tributaries leads to recurrence.
explanation.technical_details: The SFJ lies in the femoral triangle, covered by the cribriform fascia which contains the saphenous hiatus. The GSV courses anteromedially in the thigh and curves laterally at the SFJ to enter the anteriomedial aspect of the CFV. The terminal valve lies within 1-2cm of the junction. The preterminal valve lies 2-4cm distally. Major tributaries form the 'crosse': superficial inferior epigastric (superiorly), superficial circumflex iliac (laterally), external pudendal veins (medially), plus anterolateral and posterolateral thigh veins.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: The SFJ is at the groin crease. Reality: The SFJ is 2-4cm below the inguinal ligament; the groin crease is unreliable.
Misconception: All SFJ tributaries are similar. Reality: Significant anatomic variation exists; always map with ultrasound.
Misconception: Treating the GSV trunk alone is sufficient. Reality: Incompetent tributaries (especially anterior accessory) can be independent reflux sources.

anatomic_landmarks.depth: 2-4cm deep to skin (varies with body habitus)
anatomic_landmarks.relation_to_femoral_artery: CFV and SFJ lie medial to CFA
anatomic_landmarks.saphenous_hiatus: Opening in cribriform fascia for GSV passage

terminal_valve.function: Prevents reflux from CFV into GSV
terminal_valve.significance: First valve to fail in primary varicose veins

preterminal_valve.significance: Backup protection, may prevent extensive reflux if terminal fails

tributary_anatomy.crosse_definition: The constellation of tributaries at the SFJ
major_tributaries: Superficial inferior epigastric vein - drains lower abdomen
Superficial circumflex iliac vein - drains lateral hip
External pudendal veins (superficial and deep) - drain perineum
tributary_anatomy.variation: Significant individual variation in tributary pattern
tributary_anatomy.clinical_significance: Incomplete ligation of tributaries is major cause of recurrence

ultrasound_identification.technique: High-frequency linear transducer, transverse and longitudinal views
key_findings: GSV entering CFV from anteromedial direction
Femoral artery lateral to femoral vein
Terminal valve motion with Valsalva or compression
ultrasound_identification.measurement: Junction diameter, GSV diameter at multiple levels

presentation: Palpable impulse at SFJ with cough or Valsalva (Brodie-Trendelenburg test)
Visible varicosities originating from SFJ distribution
Positive tourniquet test indicating SFJ reflux
diagnosis: Measure reflux duration at SFJ (>0.5 sec pathologic)
Map tributary pattern and accessory veins
Assess for common femoral vein reflux
treatment: Foam sclerotherapy (adjunct or primary for tributaries)

definition.@value: The anatomic region where the great saphenous vein terminates in the common femoral vein, characterized by the terminal valve, named tributaries forming the 'crosse', and consistent relationships to surrounding structures essential for surgical and endovenous procedures.

sources.title: Rutherford's Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

learning_objectives: Describe SFJ anatomic relationships and landmarks
Identify major tributaries of the crosse
Locate the terminal and preterminal valves
Apply SFJ knowledge to ultrasound mapping and procedure planning
clinical_pearls: SFJ is 2-4cm below inguinal ligament, 3-4cm inferolateral to pubic tubercle
Terminal valve failure = primary GSV reflux - 'first line of defense'
Always map tributaries - incompletely treated anterior accessory vein is common recurrence source
Position ablation catheter 2-5cm from SFJ to protect CFV
The 'crosse' = constellation of SFJ tributaries (superficial epigastric, circumflex iliac, external pudendal)

medicalCode.description: Asymptomatic varicose veins of unspecified lower extremity
